blacksmith.

settle this like men.

comments.author: Necromaster2077

comments.text:
Yup, the word dude has been around since at least the late 1800's. It 
originally was similar to a dandy, or someone who was overly caring of 
their appearance, dainty. In the West, it became synonimous with city 
slicker, and those wealthy city folk who decided to venture out west for 
adventure. The places built for them to stay were called dude ranches.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dude

comments.text:
+Becky Kennedy Maybe another reason why Doc was giving Marty that look at 
1:33 was because, a little earlier before Marty confronted Tannen, Tannen 
was holding Doc hostage and Doc told Marty to run and save himself 
(probably saying to just catch the train with the delorean and head back to 
1985) and maybe that look at 1:33 was like Doc was saying "if you only took 
my advice to run and save yourself, you wouldn't have gotten shot" and/or 
it was a look to say "why did you think about settling it like men with 
Tannen who is the meanest cowboy ever that never listens to reason?"

comments.text:
+Becky Kennedy Yes that's true.  I remember Doc's gun wasn't loaded when he 
tried to shoot the Libyans.  I guess he couldn't pretend it was loaded and 
point it to them saying "drop your gun" since the Libyan was pointing a gun 
at him ready to pull the trigger.  Probably even if Doc did pretend it was 
loaded, it wouldn't have mattered because he (Doc) was wearing a 
bulletproof vest to be prepared for them.
comments.author: afriendofbean

comments.text:
+afriendofbean Marty might have not known this, but the only reason why Doc 
dropped his guns down at the Libyans was because his didn't have any 
bullets.

comments.text:
Yes that was funny.  He was also looking like he was saying "if you didn't 
drop the gun, you wouldn't have gotten shot."  (Of course, Doc dropped his 
gun on the first film against the Libbian's which surprised Marty and then 
Doc got shot because of dropping his gun).  Also, as Doc was giving that 
look here, it was probably a disappointed look too feeling that how can he 
go back to the year 1985 without Marty if Marty's parents feel that Doc is 
a great counselor to him.

comments.text:
I know there are many logical gaps in the BttF movies, but honestly, I 
really don´t care. They still work better than many many other movies about 
time travel - just look at "Looper", this movie is one giant stupid mess 
and almost nothing makes sence, especially at the end.

And they were instant classics, you can watch them today, no matter if for 
the first or the 364th time, and they still work their magic. They just 
don´t grow old.﻿
comments.author: Furzkampfbomber

comments.text:
+Livingston Hampton
Oh, that part was hard to miss. And yes, I've got it, he was such a hero 
and he killed himself after he had some kind of epiphany and discovered his 
good site. Which was especially believable after he betrayed his best and 
only friend for some barrels of silver.

Apart from that Gordon-Levitt killing himself simply makes no freaking 
sense at all, timetravel- and logic-wise. Because from the moment his 
younger self killed itself, the whole story simply could and would not have 
happened.

The younger version of Gordon-Levitts best friend getting tortured and his 
older version suffering the consequences did not only make no sense, it was 
simply beyond stupid.

First, his younger self got  killed in the end of the process, so his older 
self would not have just physically disappeared, but with his "trail" 
through history still intact - this whole part of the story would have 
never happened. The older version of himself, causing all this turmoil, 
could have never been send back in time to get killed - simply because he 
would have never existed.

(Something BttF did right - Marty's parents not meeting in the past would 
have resulted in him bever been born, for instance.)

And "older friend" watching in terror how his fingers disappear? Come 
ooon... Assuming "younger friend" would have not get killed in the end, 
"older friend" simply would have arrived without his fingers. He also would 
not have all of a sudden not be able to reach the gas pedal of his car, 
because he would have been legless already when he arrived in the past. He 
would *not* all of a sudden been surprised be the fact that he, suddenly 
legless, can't reach the gas pedal anymore and he would surely not *have 
been worn long pants* with his legs ending at his knees.

So yes, other then you obviously, I did pay attention and other than you I 
am not willing to completely throw even the tiniest rest of logic in the 
garbage bin, just because Gordon-Levitt did something supposedly heroic.
comments.author: Furzkampfbomber

comments.text:
You obviously did not pay enough attention to Looper to think the ending 
made no sense. Joseph Gordon-Levitt's character sacrificed himself to save 
Emily Blunt's character and so that her son would not stray from the right 
path and become a killer. That's sensible enough for me.
comments.author: Livingston Hampton

comments.text:
Yes, I have heard things said like that in other movies. Instead of saying 
"settling it like men", they say they will drop all their weapons on the 
ground and the only weapon they will use is their fists to fight.

comments.text:
Right, except that's not what the saying originally meant. It literally 
meant fistfight. 'Sit down and talk this over' is a fairly recent change, 
actually.
comments.author: matohibiki

comments.text:
When I hear people say "settling this like men" they say they usually mean 
"talk it over" but Marty had no choice but to do fistfight at the end with 
Tannen for defense. Also, I was just giving my opinion since a lot of 
people give their opinions on YouTube videos whether it's a movie, or a 
cartoon, or any other reason. People always give their opinions on certain 
scenes or spots on what they saw or heard and how they felt.
comments.author: afriendofbean

comments.text:
....'Settling this like men' means 'fistfight'. Though I pray to God you 
were just being sarcastic in a rambling, aimless sort of way.
comments.author: matohibiki

comments.text:
Good point, since Marty told Tannen that they shouldn't kill each other and 
just talk it over like men which is the reason why when Tannen said to 
Marty to take out his gun (draw) and Marty said "no" and why Marty dropped 
his gun because of wanting to talk it over with him like a man. So I guess 
Tannen's henchman felt sorry in their hearts after hearing what a nice 
thing Marty said and decided to become good guys but still ran away knowing 
Tannen was getting arrested but got arrested too.
comments.author: afriendofbean

comments.text:
Because Mar- sorry, Clint called Tannen out on being a man, and Tannen just 
shot him in cold blood. That's not how a duel is supposed to go at all. 
It's basically breaking the Code of the West (theatrically, of course). 
It's the only thing that keeps you from being murdered in cold blood. You 
straight-up murder a man, and you lose any sort of immunity you once had, 
and whoever comes for you next, WILL be shooting to kill. No mercy given. 
In short, it was a very dumb thing for Tannen to do.
comments.author: matohibiki

comments.text:
Why are Buford Tannen's henchman not looking very happy that he shot Marty 
from 1:22-1:23 and from 1:33-1:35? They are looking at Buford like they are 
saying "shame on you for killing him" and then looking at Marty (who they 
think is Clint Eastwood) like they are saying "that's very sad." (I thought 
they would be feeling happy and laughing too like Buford Tannen since they 
are his henchmen).
